step.context: %text What is $z$ in terms of $x$ and $y$ if $\tan^{-1}x+\tan^{-1}y=\tan^{-1}z$. %
\tan^{-1}3x+\tan^{-1}2x=\dfrac{\pi}{4} \\ %text For what value of $x$ is the above true? %
step.reason: \begin{align} &\tan^{-1}3x+\tan^{-1}2x=\dfrac{\pi}{4} \\ \implies &\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{3x+2x}{1-3x\cdot 2x}\right) =\dfrac{\pi}{4} \\ \implies &6x^2+5x-1=0 \\ \implies &x=-1,\dfrac{1}{6} \end{align} \\ %text $x=-1$ results in $\tan^{-1}(-3)$ and $\tan^{-1}(-2)$. Since these are negative values, the angle that they represent is no longer in the first quadrant (where $\tan$ is positive). Therefore, we ignore $x=-1$. %
